title: Calculate transfer functions
text: vignette explains, two special cases isotope diffusion polar firn time uncertainty layer-counted chronologies, calculate spectral transfer functions describe expected loss spectral power function frequency. time uncertainty, loss applies spectrum common signal recorded spatial average array layer-counted proxy records (“stacked” record); diffusion, applies loss average spectral power individual isotope records. documentation utilises examples code calculating transfer functions DML WAIS isotope records studied Münch Laepple (2018). , also find detailed description basic method (see Appendix B).

title: Calculate transfer functions
text: modelling time uncertainty suggested package simproxyage required, need check whether available: case installed simproxyage try rebuild vignette, receive message installation instructions . vignette still build, though without actually calculating time uncertainty transfer function.
code: library(proxysnr) has.simproxyage <- proxysnr:::check.simproxyage() #>  #> Checking simproxyage availability... ok.

title: Calculate transfer functions
text: First, set general variables parameters required calculations. convenience, list objects used saving transfer functions: specific resolution created surrogate white noise time series used diffusion calculations, , general, higher resolution compared target resolution isotope records adopted. necessary numerical stability diffusion results high-frequency end. , target resolution isotope records 1 yr (annual resolution) simulation resolution 0.5 yr proven sufficient numerical stability results: Finally, specify number Monte Carlo simulations used obtain transfer functions. general, average large number simulations needed reduce spectral uncertainties obtain smooth estimates. However, reduce computation time, small number simulations used vignette: Note results Münch Laepple (2018), ns set 100,000, required computation time 1–3 hours depending dataset (using 2.4 GHz Intel Core i5 processor).
code: # for diffusion transfer function dtf <- list() # for time uncertainty transfer function ttf <- list() res <- 1/2 ns <- 10

title: Calculate transfer functions
text: following, document dataset-specific parameters needed calculations along example DML1 dataset isotope records. Specify number proxy records (“cores”) studied array: Specify time axis common proxy records array units original (target) resolution records (, years), gives number proxy data points: Specify time points age control points time uncertainty assumed zero: Set rate random process perturbs proxy record chronologies, rate missing double-counting layer; use symmetric rates : (Specify numeric vector two entries use asymmetric rates.) diffusion simulations, estimates diffusion length (units record resolution) needed function time since deposition. Along proxysnr, diffusion length estimates DML WAIS cores provided internal dataset diffusion.length. Calculation estimates documented package source ./data-raw/produce-internal-data.R, . root package source directory. information see publication Münch Laepple (2018). can now run diffusion model, time uncertainty model Gaussian white noise surrogate data:
code: nc <- 15 # set time axis t <- seq(1994, 1801) # number of proxy data points nt <- length(t) acp <- c(1994, 1884, 1816, 1810) rate <- 0.013 set.seed(4122018) dtf$dml1 <- CalculateDiffusionTF(nt = nt / res, nc = nc, ns = ns,                                  sigma = proxysnr:::diffusion.length$dml1[, -1],                                  res = res) set.seed(4122018) if (has.simproxyage) {   suppressMessages(     ttf$dml1 <- CalculateTimeUncertaintyTF(t = t, acp = acp, nt = nt, nc = nc,                                            ns = ns, rate = rate,                                            surrogate.fun = rnorm)   ) } else {   ttf <- NULL }

title: Calculate transfer functions
text: run calculations DML2 isotope records… … WAIS isotope records:
code: set.seed(4122018)  nc <- 3 t <- seq(1994, 1000) nt <- length(t) acp <- c(1994, 1884, 1816, 1810, 1459, 1259) rate <- 0.013  dtf$dml2 <- CalculateDiffusionTF(nt = nt / res, nc = nc, ns = ns,                                  sigma = proxysnr:::diffusion.length$dml2[, -1],                                  res = res)  if (has.simproxyage) {   suppressMessages(     ttf$dml2 <- CalculateTimeUncertaintyTF(t = t, acp = acp, nt = nt, nc = nc,                                            ns = ns, rate = rate,                                            surrogate.fun = rnorm)   ) } set.seed(4122018)  nc <- 5 t <- seq(2000, 1800) nt <- length(t) acp <- c(2000, 1992, 1964, 1885, 1837, 1816, 1810) rate <- 0.027  dtf$wais <- CalculateDiffusionTF(nt = nt / res, nc = nc, ns = ns,                                  sigma = proxysnr:::diffusion.length$wais[, -1],                                  res = res)  if (has.simproxyage) {   suppressMessages(     ttf$wais <- CalculateTimeUncertaintyTF(t = t, acp = acp, nt = nt, nc = nc,                                            ns = ns, rate = rate,                                            surrogate.fun = rnorm)   ) }

title: Calculate transfer functions
text: obtained transfer functions can plotted : Fig. 1: Estimates spectral transfer functions effects site-specific diffusion () time uncertainty (b) three arrays firn-core isotope records: DML1 (black), DML2 (red) WAIS (blue) (studied Münch Laepple, 2018). Plotted case average transfer function 10 Monte Carlo simulations. transfer functions simulations ns = 10^5 used shown Münch Laepple (2018), Fig. B1, provided along proxysnr variables ?diffusion.tf ?time.uncertainty.tf. can plotted simply omitting transfer function parameters plot call:
code: PlotTF(dtf = dtf, ttf = ttf,        names = c("DML1", "DML2", "WAIS"),        col = c("black", "firebrick", "dodgerblue")) PlotTF(names = c("DML1", "DML2", "WAIS"), dtf.threshold = 0.5,        col = c("black", "firebrick", "dodgerblue"))

title: Calculate transfer functions
text: Münch, T. Laepple, T.: climate signal contained decadal- centennial-scale isotope variations Antarctic ice cores?, Clim. Past, 14, 2053-2070, doi: 10.5194/cp-14-2053-2018, 2018.

title: Plot results of Münch & Laepple (2018)
text: vignette documents steps needed obtain main results presented Münch Laepple (2018) along plotting respective main figures.

title: Plot results of Münch & Laepple (2018)
text: Produce main spectral results DML1, DML2 WAIS oxygen isotope datasets (.e. raw corrected signal noise spectra): function wrapper main package functions ObtainArraySpectra() SeparateSignalFromNoise() calls two functions datasets specified input WrapSpectralResults(). function ObtainArraySpectra() used, specific dataset, calculate individual spectra, corresponding mean spectrum spectrum stacked record (thus, average isotope record time domain); SeparateSignalFromNoise() used obtain raw corrected signal noise spectra dataset. datasets analysed paper provided along proxysnr variables ?dml ?wais. applied transfer functions correct loss high-frequency spectral power effects diffusion time uncertainty included package datasets ?diffusion.tf ?time.uncertainty.tf, respectively; see vignette vignette("calculate-transfer-functions") details obtaining functions. output WrapSpectralResults() list spectral results datasets providing estimated signal, noise signal--noise ratio spectra () without correction applied (“raw”), (ii) applying diffusion correction (“corr.diff.”), (iii) applying time uncertainty correction (“corr.t.unc.”), (iv) applying corrections (“corr.full”): datasets, can omit one two transfer functions call WrapSpectralResults() case raw, .e. uncorrected, partially corrected signal noise spectra returned datasets.
code: library(proxysnr) library(magrittr) DWS <- WrapSpectralResults(     dml1 = dml$dml1, dml2 = dml$dml2, wais = wais,     diffusion = diffusion.tf,     time.uncertainty = time.uncertainty.tf,     df.log = c(0.15, 0.15, 0.1)) ls.str(DWS) #> dml1 : List of 4 #>  $ raw            :List of 4 #>  $ corr.diff.only :List of 4 #>  $ corr.t.unc.only:List of 4 #>  $ corr.full      :List of 4 #> dml2 : List of 4 #>  $ raw            :List of 4 #>  $ corr.diff.only :List of 4 #>  $ corr.t.unc.only:List of 4 #>  $ corr.full      :List of 4 #> wais : List of 4 #>  $ raw            :List of 4 #>  $ corr.diff.only :List of 4 #>  $ corr.t.unc.only:List of 4 #>  $ corr.full      :List of 4

title: Plot results of Münch & Laepple (2018)
code: dml$dml1 %>%   ObtainArraySpectra(df.log = 0.12) %>%   PlotArraySpectra(marker = DWS$dml1$corr.full$f.cutoff[2],                    ylab = expression(                      "Power spectral density " * "(\u2030"^{2}%.%"yr)"))

what: Plot DML and WAIS signal and noise spectra (Figure 2)
title: Plot results of Münch & Laepple (2018)
code: proxysnr:::muench_laepple_fig02(DWS)

what: Plot frequency dependence of signal-to-noise ratios (Figure 3)
title: Plot results of Münch & Laepple (2018)
text: Plot final signal--noise ratio spectra combining DML datasets including additional logarithmic smoothing visual purposes:
code: (SNR <- proxysnr:::PublicationSNR(DWS)) %>%   PlotSNR(f.cut = TRUE, names = c("DML", "WAIS"),           col = c("black", "dodgerblue4"))

what: Plot estimated correlation with common signal (Figure 4)
title: Plot results of Münch & Laepple (2018)
text: Calculate estimated correlation stacked isotope record underlying common signal function records averaged temporal averaging period (.e. resolution) records, plot :
code: # for the DMl data SNR$dml %>%   ObtainStackCorrelation(N = 1 : 20,                          limits = c(1 / 100, SNR$dml$f.cutoff[2])) %>%   PlotStackCorrelation(label = expression(bold("a.")~"DML"),                        ylim = c(NA, 50)) # for the WAIS data SNR$wais %>%   ObtainStackCorrelation(N = 1 : 20,                          limits = c(1 / 100, SNR$wais$f.cutoff[2])) %>%   PlotStackCorrelation(label = expression(bold("b.")~"WAIS"),                        ylim = c(NA, 50))

what: Plot comparison of DML and Trench noise spectra (Figure 5)
title: Plot results of Münch & Laepple (2018)
text: compare noise spectrum DML firn-core array (“array scale”) noise spectrum T15 trench oxygen isotope data (“local scale”). latter supplied internal package variable t15.noise automatically loaded plotting function:
code: proxysnr:::muench_laepple_fig05(SNR)

title: Introduction to proxysnr
text: proxysnr can apply spectral analyses climate proxy records obtained spatial array proxy observation locations, e.g. ice cores, marine sediment cores, tree rings, etc., derive power spectral density (PSD, , short, spectrum) record’s common signal PSD local noise (details see Münch Laepple, 2018) work proxysnr, supply proxy records form list, data frame, list element data column representing one proxy observation locations, proxy data sampled time, depth, given variable, equal intervals. Note equidistance sampling intervals mandatory obtain correct spectra. showcase analyses available proxysnr create artifical proxy dataset mimicks five observation locations, sampling proxy data 1000 sampling points:
code: set.seed(20241030)  # five "cores" (proxy observation locations) nc <- 5 # number of sampling points (e.g. time steps) at each location nt <- 1000  # simulate a common climate signal as an AR-1 process clim <- as.numeric(arima.sim(model = list(ar = 0.7), n = nt)) # simulate the independent proxy noise as a white noise process noise <- as.data.frame(replicate(nc, rnorm(n = nt, sd = 1.5)))  # create a data frame (i.e. a "spatial array") of five "cores" that record the # same climate signal (scaled to make it relatively a bit stronger) but # independent noise cores <- 1.2 * clim + noise

what: Obtaining and plotting the proxy array spectra
title: Introduction to proxysnr
text: first step calculate PSD proxy record, obtain average spectrum individual spectra, get spectrum data series averaging across proxy records (“stacked” record); handled function ObtainArraySpectra(). need set sampling resolution via parameter res (chosen arbitrarily ) order obtain correct spectral units, can apply smoothing raw spectral estimates (parameter df.log) reduce spectral uncertainty: output list contains attribute array.par stores information underlying proxy record array, namely number records (“nc”), number sampling points per record (“nt”), sampling resolution (“res”), proxysnr functions information available. function PlotArraySpectra() directly plots results:  plot displays spectra function inverse spectral frequency, e.g. time period, often intuitive interpret. proxy record’s spectrum shown thin grey line (however, can change colours likings), mean spectrum individual spectra plotted thick black line, averages spectral uncertainty individual spectra thus delivers accurate representation average proxy PSD. proxy record variations indepedent noise, spectrum stacked record (thick brown line) follow line mean spectrum divided number records, .e. black dashed line plot. Hence, PSD spectrum stacked record exceeds line (blue shaded area) results proxy variability common records, spectral energy lost (red shaded area) represents independent noise variability. need save intermediate results, can also pipe workflow, following always show combined, piped workflow order highlight proxysnr functions linked.
code: arrspec <- ObtainArraySpectra(cores, res = 2, df.log = 0.1)  names(arrspec) #> [1] "single" "mean"   "stack" attr(arrspec, "array.par") #>   nc   nt  res  #>    5 1000    2 PlotArraySpectra(arrspec, remove = 0, xlim = c(2000, 2), ylim = c(0.05, 50),                  xlab = "Period (a.u.)", ylab = "Power spectral density") cores %>%   ObtainArraySpectra(res = 2, df.log = 0.1) %>%   PlotArraySpectra(remove = 0, xlim = c(2000, 2), ylim = c(0.05, 50),                    xlab = "Period (a.u.)", ylab = "Power spectral density")

title: Introduction to proxysnr
text: previous plot visually insightful, blue red shaded areas proportional actual signal noise spectra (see Münch Laepple, 2018 details); instead calculated using SeparateSignalFromNoise() delivers also spectrum signal--noise ratio, important quantity interpret proxy variability terms climate variability. two plotting routines available proxysnr, LPlot() LLines(), plot spectral object returned functions automatically double-logarithmic axes. follow concept base R’s plot() lines() functions can thus make fresh spectrum plot add spectrum existing plot. plot results analyses spec can write  can test whether estimated noise spectrum indeed reproduces standard deviation 1.5 given white noise process:
code: spec <- cores %>%   ObtainArraySpectra(res = 2, df.log = 0.1) %>%   SeparateSignalFromNoise()  str(spec) #> List of 3 #>  $ signal:List of 2 #>   ..$ freq: num [1:500] 0.0005 0.001 0.0015 0.002 0.0025 0.003 0.0035 0.004 0.0045 0.005 ... #>   ..$ spec: num [1:500] 8.21 13.57 19.86 38.26 44.7 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "class")= chr "spec" #>  $ noise :List of 2 #>   ..$ freq: num [1:500] 0.0005 0.001 0.0015 0.002 0.0025 0.003 0.0035 0.004 0.0045 0.005 ... #>   ..$ spec: num [1:500] 1.56 3.04 3.72 4.03 4.04 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "class")= chr "spec" #>  $ snr   :List of 2 #>   ..$ freq: num [1:500] 0.0005 0.001 0.0015 0.002 0.0025 0.003 0.0035 0.004 0.0045 0.005 ... #>   ..$ spec: num [1:500] 5.26 4.47 5.33 9.5 11.08 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "class")= chr "spec" #>  - attr(*, "array.par")= Named num [1:3] 5 1000 2 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:3] "nc" "nt" "res" op <- par(mar = c(5, 5, 0.5, 0.5), las = 1,           cex.main = 1.5, cex.lab = 1.5, cex.axis = 1.25)  LPlot(spec$signal, inverse = TRUE,       xlab = "Period (a.u.)", ylab = "Power spectral density",       xlim = c(2000, 2), ylim = c(0.1, 50), col = "dodgerblue4", lwd = 2) LLines(spec$noise, inverse = TRUE, col = "firebrick4", lwd = 2) legend("bottomleft", c("Signal", "Noise"), col = c("dodgerblue4", "firebrick4"),        lty = 1, lwd = 2, bty = "n")  LPlot(spec$snr, inverse = TRUE, xlab = "Period (a.u.)", ylab = "SNR",       xlim = c(2000, 2), ylim = c(0.1, 50), col = "black", lwd = 2)  par(op) df <- diff(spec$noise$freq)[1] sqrt(2 * df * sum(spec$noise$spec)) # ok! #> [1] 1.497102

title: Introduction to proxysnr
text: Since confidence intervals signal, noise, SNR spectra obtained analytically, proxysnr offers estimate parametric bootstrapping procedure based Monte Carlo simulation surrogate data: plotting routines LPlot() LLines() automatically add shading confidence intervals plot, available, plotting code can used reproduce plots now including just estimated confidence intervals:
code: spec <- cores %>%   ObtainArraySpectra(res = 2, df.log = 0.1) %>%   SeparateSignalFromNoise() %>%   EstimateCI(nmc = 10, df.log = 0.1, ci.df.log = 0.05)

what: Correction of signal and noise spectra
title: Introduction to proxysnr
text: archiving, proxy records may subject smoothing, e.g. firn ice diffusion, marine sediments bioturbation. Furthermore, proxy records dated chronologies may uncertain records, time uncertainty affecting reconstruction common signal. proxysnr offers correct estimated signal noise spectra effects supplying respective transfer functions SeparateSignalFromNoise() via function parameters diffusion time.uncertainty. transfer functions describe loss spectral power due smoothing uncertain chronologies need assessed provided user. two special cases can apply proxysnr directly calculate transfer functions: firn diffusion (function CalculateDiffusionTF()) time uncertainty layer-counted chronologies (function CalculateTimeUncertaintyTF()); see also Münch Laepple (2018) details processes implemented estimation, vignette("calculate-transfer-functions") details using two functions. Proxy records also contain measurement noise. estimate magnitude spectral shape, can supply information SeparateSignalFromNoise() via measurement.noise parameter, returned noise SNR spectra corrected measurement noise, .e. take account proxy-specific noise created archiving process.

title: Introduction to proxysnr
text: proxysnr functions can use conduct visualise analyses: GetIntegratedSNR() delivers ratio integrated signal noise spectra, corresponds SNR specific sampling resolution; ObtainStackCorrelation() calculates expected correlation stack proxy records common climate signal function number records averaged records’ sampling resolution (see Fig. 4 Münch Laepple, 2018 example); PlotStackCorrelation() directly plot output ObtainStackCorrelation(); PlotSNR() plot several SNR datasets one figure; PlotTF() make plot transfer functions obtained CalculateDiffusionTF() /CalculateTimeUncertaintyTF().

title: Introduction to proxysnr
text: proxysnr ships four package datasets: ?dml contains oxygen isotope data 15 firn cores Dronning Maud Land (DML), Antarctica (Graf et al., 2002); ?wais contains oxygen isotope data 5 firn cores West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS; Steig, 2013); ?diffusion.tf contains pre-calculated diffusion transfer functions DML WAIS isotope records; ?time.uncertainty.tf contains pre-calculated time uncertainty transfer functions records. datasets can used test functions proxysnr, basis analyses Münch Laepple (2018); see also vignette("plot-muench-laepple-figures") reproducing results.

text: proxysnr implements method working spectral domain separate common signal local noise recorded spatial network climate proxy records, yields estimate timescale dependence proxy signal--noise ratio (SNR). method allows correction estimated spectra effects time uncertainty, proxy smoothing processes (e.g. diffusion), measurement noise. method introduced detail explained Münch Laepple (2018), applied oxygen isotope records Antarctic firn ice cores. proxysnr implemented Dr. Thomas Münch contributions Dr. Thomas Laepple, Dr. Andrew Dolman, Dr. Torben Kunz, Dr. Mara McPartland. title: Diffusion transfer function — CalculateDiffusionTF
code: CalculateDiffusionTF(   nt,   nc,   ns,   sigma,   res = 1,   window = NULL,   coherent = FALSE,   df.log = NULL,   verbose.output = FALSE,   ... )

title: Diffusion transfer function — CalculateDiffusionTF
text: nt length modelled isotope records (.e. number data points record). nc number cores modelled core array. ns number Monte Carlo simulations estimating transfer function. sigma numeric vector length nt numeric array dimension nt * nc providing diffusion length values. nt diffusion length values assumed correspond respective nt isotope values. numeric vector provided, assumed diffusion lengths valid nc cores. array provided, column provides diffusion lengths respective core. Note units diffusion length must match units res. res sampling (e.g., temporal) resolution isotope data; determines frequency axis transfer function. window length-2 vector giving start end time (within 1:nt) offering possibility use subset total length simulated records transfer function analysis, default NULL means use records' entire lengths. coherent TRUE, nc identical white noise time series assumed estimate transfer function; else (default) nc independent noise series. df.log width Gaussian kernel logarithmic frequency units smooth spectral estimates; NULL (default) suppresses smoothing. general, smoothing necessary sufficiently large number Monte Carlo simulations (parameter ns) used; nevertheless, can switched transfer function still appears noisy. verbose.output logical controlling size return object; per default, transfer function spectrum returned, else also spectra whose ratio determines transfer function (see Details). ... additional parameters passed spectral estimation function SpecMTM.

title: Diffusion transfer function — CalculateDiffusionTF
text: either spectral object (?spec.object) transfer function   verbose.output = FALSE (default), list spectral objects   signal, diffused ratio, providing averages   ns simulations : signal: undiffused spectrum; diffused: diffused spectrum; ratio ratio (diffused/undiffused), .e. transfer     function.

title: Diffusion transfer function — CalculateDiffusionTF
text: approach described detail Münch Laepple (2018). brief, nc Gaussian white noise time series created diffused average time series calculated. process repeated ns times. ns realisations, spectra average diffused undiffused records calculated; subsequently, ns spectra averaged, ratio average diffused average undiffused spectrum yields spectral transfer function. Diffusion modelled convolution undiffused record Gaussian standard deviation given diffusion length sigma. spectral estimates calculated using Thomson’s multitaper method three windows linear detrending analysis.

title: Time uncertainty transfer function — CalculateTimeUncertaintyTF
text: function implements empirical Monte Carlo approach estimate spectral transfer function effect time uncertainty spatial average common proxy signal recorded given core array. requires suggested package simproxyage; package installed, receive installation instructions upon calling function.

title: Time uncertainty transfer function — CalculateTimeUncertaintyTF
code: CalculateTimeUncertaintyTF(   t = 100:1,   acp = c(t[1], NA),   nt = length(t),   nc = 1,   ns = 100,   model = "poisson",   rate = 0.05,   resize = 1,   surrogate.fun = stats::rnorm,   fun.par = NULL,   pad = TRUE,   df.log = NULL,   verbose.output = FALSE,   ... )

title: Time uncertainty transfer function — CalculateTimeUncertaintyTF
text: t numeric vector integer values providing reference chronology age perturbations (starting youngest age). acp numeric vector age control points age uncertainty assumed zero. Per default, two-element vector first element start age (t[1]) second element NA resulting unconstrained age perturbation process; see details handling age control points. nt length records (.e. number data points) simulate; per default set length(t). nc number cores modelled core array. ns number Monte Carlo simulations estimating transfer function. model name string random process use realising age perturbations; must either "poisson" (default) "bernoulli"; see Comboul et al. (2014) details two models. rate numeric vector probability rate(s) age band perturbed; can specify vector two rates first entry probability missing band second entry probability double-counting band. single value specified (per default 0.05), symmetric perturbations assumed. resize resizing option case shorter/longer original time axes: 0 = resize, -1 = resize shortest realisation, 1 = resize longest realisation (default). surrogate.fun random number generator use creating noise time series; per default, Gaussian white noise created using base R function rnorm. fun.par otional list additional parameters passed surrogate.fun. pad Strong age perturbations may result time series reach final age reference chronology – shall resulting NA values (case resize = 1) set 0 spectral estimation? Defaults TRUE. influence spectral estimation provided number NA values small compared total length time series. df.log width Gaussian kernel logarithmic frequency units smooth spectral estimates; NULL (default) suppresses smoothing. general, smoothing necessary sufficiently large number Monte Carlo simulations (parameter ns) used; nevertheless, can switched transfer function still appears noisy. verbose.output logical controlling size return object; per default, transfer function spectrum returned, else also spectra whose ratio determines transfer function (see Details). ... additional parameters passed spectral estimation function SpecMTM.

title: Time uncertainty transfer function — CalculateTimeUncertaintyTF
text: either spectral object (?spec.object) transfer   function verbose.output = FALSE (default), list   spectral objects input, stack ratio, providing   averages ns simulations : input: original spectrum surrogate data; stack: spectrum spatial average         age-perturbed records; ratio: ratio (perturbed/unperturbed), .e. transfer         function.

title: Time uncertainty transfer function — CalculateTimeUncertaintyTF
text: approach described detail Münch Laepple (2018). brief, nc identical surrogate time series created age perturbed average time series calculated. process repeated ns times. ns realisations, spectra average age-perturbed original time series calculated yielding spectral transfer function. modelling time uncertainty follows approach presented Comboul et al. (2014) implemented package simproxyage. package can installed GitHub viaremotes::install_github("EarthSystemDiagnostics/simproxyage") can download package repository <https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.2025204> install package via devtools::install(). spectral estimates calculated using Thomson’s multitaper method three windows linear detrending analysis. Handling age control points (see package simproxyage details): function allows one model age uncertainty several age control points (ACP) age uncertainty evolves according model Comboul et al. (2014) age control points forced back zero time uncertainty ACPs following Brownian Bridge process. Per default, start age (.e. youngest age core top) assumed first ACP, thus, set explicitly vector acp, youngest age added first element. can specify arbitrary number additional ACPs. pair ACPs (starting core top), constrained age perturbation realisations performed following Comboul et al. (2014) model Brownian Bridge concept. last ACP equals oldest age t (.e. last proxy data point), last core segment also follows Brownian Bridge process. Alternatively, last ACP younger final age, NA added last element vector acp results unconstrained age perturbation process last core segment. ACPs lying outside time interval defined t removed vector acp warning.

title: Confidence interval estimation — EstimateCI

title: Confidence interval estimation — EstimateCI
code: EstimateCI(   spectra,   f.start = NULL,   f.end = NULL,   nmc = 10,   probs = c(0.1, 0.9),   df.log = NULL,   ci.df.log = NULL )

title: Confidence interval estimation — EstimateCI
text: spectra list spectral objects signal, noise, snr investigated proxy record array, obtained SeparateSignalFromNoise. f.start lower end frequency range power-law fit made proxy data (see Details); default NULL uses lowest frequency proxy spectra. f.end f.start upper end; default NULL uses uppermost frequency proxy spectra. nmc integer; number replications confidence interval estimation. probs length-2 numeric vector probabilities values [0,1] defining confidence interval; defaults 10-90 % interval. df.log width Gaussian kernel logarithmic frequency units smooth spectral estimates simulated data; smoothing usually necessary avoid physically implausible negative power occasionally occuring frequencies upon estimating common signal spectrum. suggested use amount smoothing actual proxy data, setting NULL (default) suppresses smoothing. ci.df.log width Gaussian smoothing kernel smooth estimated confidence intervals, merely visual purposes; NULL (default) suppresses smoothing.

title: Confidence interval estimation — EstimateCI
text: input spectra object, amended confidence intervals   signal, noise SNR spectra (element lim.1 gives upper   confidence level, element lim.2 lower level, respectively).

title: Confidence interval estimation — EstimateCI
text: parametric bootstrapping procedure confidence level estimation implemented follows. power-law fit form alpha * f^(-beta) applied actual signal noise spectra, resulting power-law coefficients used generate surrogate signal noise series simulated array mimics actual proxy record array. simulated array replicated nmc times lower upper quantiles calculated across realizations signal, noise SNR surrogates. Subsequently, quantiles scaled respective mean estimates applied multiplicatively actual proxy estimates signal, noise, SNR yield confidence intervals.

code: library(magrittr)  # create artificial proxy data as a showcase dataset nc <- 5 nt <- 1000 clim <- as.numeric(stats::arima.sim(model = list(ar = 0.7), n = nt)) noise <- as.data.frame(replicate(nc, rnorm(n = nt)))  # array of five "cores" recording the same climate but independent noise: cores <- clim + noise  # obtain the spectra and plot them cores %>%   ObtainArraySpectra(df.log = 0.05) %>%   PlotArraySpectra(xlim = c(1000, 2))   # do not omit any values on the plot cores %>%   ObtainArraySpectra(df.log = 0.05) %>%   PlotArraySpectra(remove = 0, xlim = c(1000, 2))

title: Plot proxy stack correlation — PlotStackCorrelation
code: # create a toy correlation dataset, which mimicks an increase # in correlation with timescale and with the number of cores # averaged, and plot it:  nf <- 20 nc <- 5  data <- list(   freq = seq(0.01, 0.5, length.out = nf),   correlation =     matrix(seq(0.05, 0.9, length.out = nf), nrow = nc, ncol = nf,            byrow = TRUE) +     matrix(seq(0, 0.3, length.out = nc), nrow = nc, ncol = nf) +     matrix(rnorm(nf * nc, sd = 0.02), nrow = nc, ncol = nf) ) data$correlation[data$correlation > 1] <- 1 data$correlation[data$correlation < 0] <- 0  PlotStackCorrelation(data)

title: Multitaper spectral estimate — SpecMTM
text: timeSeries time series equally spaced data, can created ts() function deltat specified. k k positive integer, number tapers, often 2*nw. nw nw positive double precision number, time-bandwidth     parameter. nFFT function pads data computing fft. nFFT indicates total length data padding. centre time series centred using one three methods: expansion     onto discrete prolate spheroidal sequences ('Slepian'), arithmetic mean ('arithMean'),     trimmed mean ('trimMean'), ('none'). dpssIN Allows user enter dpss object already     created. can save computation time Slepians  bandwidth parameter number tapers used repeatedly. returnZeroFreq Boolean variable indicating zeroth     frequency (DC component) returned applicable arrays. Ftest Boolean variable indicating Ftest result  computed returned. jackknife Boolean variable indicating jackknifed confidence intervals computed returned. jkCIProb Decimal value indicating jackknife probability calculating jackknife confidence intervals. default returns 95% confidence interval. maxAdaptiveIterations Maximum number iterations adaptive multitaper calculation. Generally convergence quick, require less 100 iterations. plot Boolean variable indicating spectrum plotted. na.action Action take NAs exist data, default     fail. returnInternals Return weighted eigencoefficients, complex mean values, . necessary extensions multitaper, including magnitude-squared coherence (function mtm.coh package). Note:   internal ($mtm) variables eigenCoefs eigenCoefWt correspond multitaper eigencoefficients. eigencoefficients correspond equation (3.4) weights, eigenCoefWt, correspond sqrt(|d_k(f)|^2) equation (5.4) Thomson's 1982 paper. square root values contained eigenCoefWt commonly used additional calculations (example: eigenCoefWt * eigenCoefs).  values returned mtm$cmv correspond estimate  coefficients hat(mu)(f) equation (13.5) Thomson (1982),  estimate hat(C)_1 frequency 1 equation (499) form Percival Walden (1993) detrend Shall time series data linearly detrended computing spectrum? Defaults TRUE. bPad Shall time series data padded computing spectrum? Defaults FALSE. ... parameters passed spec.mtm.

text: function IntegratedSNR() added, takes job calculating signal--noise ratio integrated signal noise spectra, delivers SNR corresponding varying temporal record resolutions (compared SNR specific frequency obtained SeparateSpectra(), corresponds band-pass filtered record). StackCorrelation() internally now uses new function improved code structure. Parameter N StackCorrelation() longer indicates maximum number records treated directly vector record numbers; call previously used N = 5 now needs use N  = 1 : 5. rather verbose output StackCorrelation() reduced minimum needed - list two elements: frequency axis correlation matrix. Output StackCorrelation() piped plotting function PlotStackCorrelation() adapted accordingly.
